awd_titl_txt: MPS-Ascend: Eigenvector Statistics of the Adjacency Operator of Graphs
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is funded in whole or in part under the American Rescue Plan Act of 2021 (Public Law 117-2). PI Theo McKenzie is awarded a National Science Foundation Mathematical and Physical Sciences Ascending Postdoctoral Research Fellowship (NSF MPS-Ascend) to conduct a program of research and activities related to broadening participation by groups underrepresented in STEM. This fellowship to Dr. McKenzie supports the research project entitled "MPS-Ascend: Eigenvector Statistics of the Adjacency Operator of Graphs", under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The host institution for the fellowship is Harvard University, and the sponsoring scientist is Dr. Hong-Tzer Yau.

The project's goal is to study the structure of eigenvectors of operators on graphs. The PI will work in three research directions: deduce eigenvector and eigenvalue statistics such as the number of nodal domains of random and semi-random graphs using the combinatorial structure of the graph to prove eigenvector delocalization; bound the number of eigenvalues near the edge of the spectrum for operators on graphs and manifolds using PI's prior research; and generalize known results in quantum ergodicity to graph families with arbitrary limits to further elucidate the connection between eigenvector statistics of a graph family and those of the infinite limit. PI's broadening participation activities are two-fold. One, the PI will leverage his experience as a lead instructor at the associate degree program at San Quentin State Prison, to teach and introduce a more advanced curriculum in the college programs at prisons in Massachusetts, that have a high population of racial minorities. This project aims to directly help those who are incarcerated learn higher level math and thereby gain agency. Second, using his own experience as a Black mathematician, create a community of postdocs and graduate students from underrepresented backgrounds at Harvard. This group will interact with each other and work on personal development activities thereby creating a welcoming environment for researchers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The outcomes of my project can be split into parts more focused on intellectual merit and then parts more focused on broader impacts. I will address both:

 

Intellectual Merit.

My year at Harvard saw a number of intellectual breakthroughs. Overall, my goal was to elucidate the structure of eigenvectors as a crucial part of the analysis of discrete operators, both in probabilistic and deterministic settings. Thanks to the fellowship, I was able to focus on my research program and come up with significant results. I have broken down my results into various projects.

A general guiding principle since Berry’s conjecture in the 70’s is that for a quantum chaotic system, the solutions to the Schrödinger equation will have random statistics, in that they have the statistics of Gaussians with fixed covariance. This is expected to be true for continuous systems as well as discrete systems. A discrete system can be represented by a graph, and my research during this project is towards showing when chaotic systems have these statistics.

An example of a chaotic system is a random graph. During my year, I showed that eigenvectors of random graphs exhibit Gaussian behavior. One important parameter is that of nodal domains, which count fluctuations in high dimensions. High energy eigenfunctions should have many fluctuations, therefore should have many nodal domains. We showed that sparse random graphs have many nodal domains for the highest energy eigenvalues, confirming behavior noticed by computer tests in 2011. Another project argued for a new notion of the idea of a nodal domain of a signed graph, in the hope that it will let us better understand the equivalent notion of a nodal set when system with both positive and negative relations occur in the system. We rigorously give a general theorem on the number of nodal domains for a fixed signed graph, then give the number for a random signed graph with both positive and negative edges.

For some sparse models, we expect localized eigenvectors for the most positive and negative eigenvalues, as these energies will “focus” around small regions in a phenomenon known as Anderson localization. It had been conjectured that random graphs with average expected degree would have this localization, which we showed using novel estimations of eigenvectors in small neighborhoods.

Outside of random models, there are two results in the deterministic setting I wish to highlight as well. Quantum ergodicity is an idea of eigenfunction equidistribution that comes from manifolds. There is an equivalent notion for graphs, however, previously this was only known for general families if graphs were expanders and high girth. We found general families of graphs that satisfy neither of these properties and yet are quantum ergodic. These are families of period graphs. These graphs have nice mathematical structure and can be analyzed using theorems relevant to quantum physics.

The other project deals more directly with computer science. A central goal of the field is to construct graphs that are optimal or near optimal in various metrics of connectivity. For vertex expansion, we simply count the number of vertices leaving a subset versus those staying within. Vertex expanders, and its weaker version unique neighbor expanders, have applications in error correcting codes and high dimensional geometry. Previously, unique neighbor expanders were only known to exist for specific degrees. We show that in fact they exist for all degrees that are sufficiently large.

 

Broader Impacts

The main goal of broader impacts in my solicitation was to help build the prison education programs at correctional institutions in Massachusetts. I spent two semesters working at MCI-Framingham, a women’s medium security prison. For the first semester, I worked in the Boston University Prison Education Program, teaching elementary algebra, as part of a program for students to receive college credit. We had a strong class of students who got a lot out of the course. 6 students passed the course and received college credit.

In the second semester, I worked for the Petey Greene program in a class that served as preparation for college. Here, I coordinated a syllabus with other prison programs in order to have a strong math program that works well for students.

Along with my work at MCI-Framingham, I served as a mentor for five Harvard undergraduates from underrepresented backgrounds on campus, meeting with them monthly to talk about their experiences and how to strategize to get what they wanted out of college. I helped students with class selection, with how to get internships, and gave general support.
